Bottlenecks are present when components can’t keep up with each other’s speed, most of the time you want your graphics card to be the one slowing things down but not too much. You should always be building your PC with screen resolution in mind, especially if you’re looking to do some GPU-intensive tasks such as gaming on modern AAA titles. But the price did drop it down, but over time that has become much less of an issue and makes it a worthy choice. Now that we’ve talked about the best GPU for your 5700X, what would push it too far and bottleneck it? Well, just about any stronger GPUs on the high end will be too much for the processor to keep up with. For the 5700X it starts with the RX 6800 XT and RTX 3080. At low resolutions, the CPU can’t keep up with them. This means any higher GPUs are also in danger of doing the same and at a higher level. Cards like the RTX 4090 and RX 7900 XTX will especially be too much for the lower processor and 1080p. There will of course be less bottlenecking at higher resolutions such as 1440p and 4K though – which is what these GPUs are designed for. If 1080p or even 1440p gaming is what you’re after, we’d suggest the RTX 4070, 4060 Ti, RX 7700 XT, or 7800XT. Otherwise look to the old generation, the RTX 3060 Ti, 3070, or RX 6700 XT as highly capable cards to sit alongside your 5700X. If you pair your fast CPU with an entry-level GPU. It will mean the processor will be held back in performance so you won’t be getting the best out of it. Especially in GPU-heavy applications like games, it will be less worth the system as it’s better to be maxing out your GPU but at a higher level. You’ll always encounter a bottleneck somewhere in your system, but pairing a 5700X and 3080 is a good combination that won’t hold back too much.
